Problem:
Consider a fluid flow governed by the Navier-Stokes equations \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + u \\cdot \\nabla u = -\\nabla p + \\nu \\Delta u + f\\), where \\(u\\) is the velocity field, \\(p\\) is the pressure, \\(\\nu\\) is the viscosity, and \\(f\\) is an external force. We investigate the effect of applying a transformation by a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to the force term \\(f\\).

If the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(f)\\) is applied to the force term at the initial condition and then the system evolves according to the Navier-Stokes equations without further intervention, will the resulting velocity field \\(u(t)\\) at time T differ from if the original force \\(f\\) was used?
Explanation: Applying \\(\\mathcal{F}(f)\\) changes the spectral components of the external force, which directly affects the driving terms in the Navier-Stokes equations. This alteration modifies the whole dynamics of the velocity field over time, resulting in a different velocity field \\(u(t)\\) at any future time T compared to using untransformed \\(f\\).
